name: oHy Hydrogen-Infused Sparkling Water
description: oHy offers a line of hydrogen-infused sparkling waters that are USDA Certified Organic and Non-GMO. They contain zero calories, sugars, or sweeteners and are infused with magnesium to enhance overall wellness. The hydrogen infusion provides antioxidant properties and a smoother, less acidic mouthfeel compared to traditional sparkling waters.

metadata.treatment_process: The water undergoes reverse osmosis filtration, followed by infusion with hydrogen gas and magnesium bicarbonate

nutrients.name: Magnesium
nutrients.risks: Excessive magnesium intake, particularly from supplements, can lead to side effects like diarrhea, nausea, low blood pressure, and in severe cases, irregular heartbeat, respiratory distress, and even coma
nutrients.benefits: Plays a vital role in bone health, cardiovascular health, migraine prevention, and regulating blood sugar levels, potentially reducing the risk of conditions like diabetes, osteoporosis, and heart disease

name: 1907water
description: 1907water is a premium bottled water enriched with essential minerals. It promotes hydration and can improve overall health but may pose risks if consumed excessively or in place of balanced nutrition.

metadata.source: New Zealandâs remote central plateau, in the alpine forests of the Kaimanawa Range from a deep underground aquifer, 680 ft directly below our bottling facility in Paeroa, New Zealand.
metadata.treatment_process: The aquifer is encased by volcanic rock and sandstone which infuses the rock minerals. The water has been carbon dated at 50,000 years old and rises to the surface under its own natural pressure.

name: Crag Sparkling Spring Water (Glass)
description: CRAG Spring Water is a premium, family-run British brand offering still and sparkling spring water. The water is bottled directly at the source in reusable glass bottles, emphasizing sustainability and purity. The water is known for its silky, creamy taste, attributed to its natural filtration through ancient rock layers.

metadata.source: At the foothills of Shutlingsloe ("Matterhorn of Cheshire") in Wildboarclough, Peak District National Park, UK
metadata.treatment_process: The water is bottled directly at the source without any chemical treatment, preserving its natural composition.

nutrients.name: Calcium
nutrients.risks: Excessive intake may increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases like myocardial infarction and kidney stones.

sources.label: The good, the bad, and the ugly of calcium supplementation: a review of calcium intake on human health

nutrients.benefits: Helps maintain bone health and prevent osteoporosis

nutrients.name: Magnesium
nutrients.risks: Excessive magnesium intake, particularly from supplements, can lead to side effects like diarrhea, nausea, low blood pressure, and in severe cases, irregular heartbeat, respiratory distress, and even coma
nutrients.benefits: Plays a vital role in bone health, cardiovascular health, migraine prevention, and regulating blood sugar levels, potentially reducing the risk of conditions like diabetes, osteoporosis, and heart disease

nutrients.name: Chloride
nutrients.risks: Excessive chloride intake, often through high sodium consumption, can lead to elevated blood pressure and increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases, while low levels may result from dehydration or certain medical conditions.
nutrients.benefits: It is crucial for maintaining proper hydration, aiding in digestion, and regulating blood pressure, while also facilitating the transport of carbon dioxide in the blood.

nutrients.name: Nitrate
nutrients.risks: Excessive nitrate intake, particularly from contaminated drinking water, can lead to methemoglobinemia (blue baby syndrome) in infants and is associated with potential cancer risks due to formation of nitrosamines.
nutrients.benefits: Nitrates are naturally occurring inorganic compounds composed of nitrogen and oxygen, commonly found in soil, water, and some vegetables.

description: Crystal-clear distilled water provides pure hydration by removing impurities and contaminants. It supports overall health and proper bodily functions, but may lack essential minerals found in natural sources.

nutrients.name: Calcium
nutrients.risks: Excessive intake may increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases like myocardial infarction and kidney stones.

sources.label: The good, the bad, and the ugly of calcium supplementation: a review of calcium intake on human health

nutrients.benefits: Helps maintain bone health and prevent osteoporosis

nutrients.name: Magnesium
nutrients.risks: Excessive magnesium intake, particularly from supplements, can lead to side effects like diarrhea, nausea, low blood pressure, and in severe cases, irregular heartbeat, respiratory distress, and even coma
nutrients.benefits: Plays a vital role in bone health, cardiovascular health, migraine prevention, and regulating blood sugar levels, potentially reducing the risk of conditions like diabetes, osteoporosis, and heart disease

nutrients.name: Potassium
nutrients.risks: High doses of potassium supplements can cause stomach upset, muscle weakness, irregular heartbeat, and potentially life-threatening hyperkalemia (high potassium levels) in those with kidney disease or taking certain medications.
nutrients.benefits: Adequate potassium intake can help lower blood pressure, reduce risk of kidney stones, improve bone health, and potentially lower risk of heart disease and stroke

nutrients.name: Calcium
nutrients.risks: Excessive intake may increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases like myocardial infarction and kidney stones.

sources.label: The good, the bad, and the ugly of calcium supplementation: a review of calcium intake on human health

nutrients.benefits: Helps maintain bone health and prevent osteoporosis

nutrients.name: Magnesium
nutrients.risks: Excessive magnesium intake, particularly from supplements, can lead to side effects like diarrhea, nausea, low blood pressure, and in severe cases, irregular heartbeat, respiratory distress, and even coma
nutrients.benefits: Plays a vital role in bone health, cardiovascular health, migraine prevention, and regulating blood sugar levels, potentially reducing the risk of conditions like diabetes, osteoporosis, and heart disease

nutrients.name: Chloride
nutrients.risks: Excessive chloride intake, often through high sodium consumption, can lead to elevated blood pressure and increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases, while low levels may result from dehydration or certain medical conditions.
nutrients.benefits: It is crucial for maintaining proper hydration, aiding in digestion, and regulating blood pressure, while also facilitating the transport of carbon dioxide in the blood.

nutrients.name: Sulphate
nutrients.risks: High concentrations of sulphates in drinking water can cause gastrointestinal discomfort, including diarrhea, especially in individuals not accustomed to it.
nutrients.benefits: At low levels, sulphates can contribute to the body's sulfur needs, which supports joint, skin, and connective tissue health.

nutrients.name: Nitrate
nutrients.risks: Excessive nitrate intake, particularly from contaminated drinking water, can lead to methemoglobinemia (blue baby syndrome) in infants and is associated with potential cancer risks due to formation of nitrosamines.
nutrients.benefits: Nitrates are naturally occurring inorganic compounds composed of nitrogen and oxygen, commonly found in soil, water, and some vegetables.

nutrients.name: Saturated fat
nutrients.risks: Excessive consumption of saturated fats may increase the risk of cardiovascular disease by raising LDL cholesterol levels in the blood.
nutrients.benefits: Saturated fats can provide energy, aid in hormone production, and help with the absorption of certain vitamins.

nutrients.name: Trans fat
nutrients.risks: Consumption of trans fats increases the risk of heart disease by raising LDL (bad) cholesterol and lowering HDL (good) cholesterol levels.
nutrients.benefits: Trans fats have no known health benefits in the human diet.

nutrients.name: Cholesterol
nutrients.risks: High levels of LDL (bad) cholesterol can increase the risk of heart disease by contributing to plaque buildup in arteries

sources.label: Dietary Cholesterol and the Lack of Evidence in Cardiovascular Disease

nutrients.benefits: Essential for many bodily functions like producing hormones, vitamin D, and bile acid

nutrients.name: Dietary Fiber
nutrients.risks: Consuming excessive amounts of fiber too quickly can lead to gastrointestinal discomfort, bloating, and may interfere with the absorption of certain minerals if intake is extremely high.
nutrients.benefits: Dietary fiber promotes digestive health, helps maintain healthy blood sugar levels, aids in weight management, and may reduce the risk of heart disease and certain cancers.

nutrients.name: Added sugars
nutrients.risks: Excessive consumption is associated with increased risks of obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cognitive decline, and some cancers

sources.label: Relationship between Added Sugars Consumption and Chronic Disease Risk Factors: Current Understanding

nutrients.benefits: No scientifically proven benefits of consuming added sugars

metadata.source: Tap water

nutrients.name: Added sugars
nutrients.risks: Excessive consumption is associated with increased risks of obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cognitive decline, and some cancers

sources.label: Relationship between Added Sugars Consumption and Chronic Disease Risk Factors: Current Understanding

nutrients.benefits: No scientifically proven benefits of consuming added sugars

nutrients.name: Potassium
nutrients.risks: High doses of potassium supplements can cause stomach upset, muscle weakness, irregular heartbeat, and potentially life-threatening hyperkalemia (high potassium levels) in those with kidney disease or taking certain medications.
nutrients.benefits: Adequate potassium intake can help lower blood pressure, reduce risk of kidney stones, improve bone health, and potentially lower risk of heart disease and stroke

nutrients.name: Vitamin C
nutrients.risks: Excessive amounts (over 2000 mg per day) can potentially cause kidney stones, severe diarrhea, nausea, and stomach cramps

sources.label: 7 Impressive Ways Vitamin C Benefits Your Body

nutrients.benefits: Boosts immunity, aids in collagen production for wound healing, enhances iron absorption, lowers blood pressure, and may reduce the risk of certain cancers, heart disease, and cataracts

nutrients.name: Added sugars
nutrients.risks: Excessive consumption is associated with increased risks of obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cognitive decline, and some cancers

sources.label: Relationship between Added Sugars Consumption and Chronic Disease Risk Factors: Current Understanding

nutrients.benefits: No scientifically proven benefits of consuming added sugars

nutrients.name: Potassium
nutrients.risks: High doses of potassium supplements can cause stomach upset, muscle weakness, irregular heartbeat, and potentially life-threatening hyperkalemia (high potassium levels) in those with kidney disease or taking certain medications.
nutrients.benefits: Adequate potassium intake can help lower blood pressure, reduce risk of kidney stones, improve bone health, and potentially lower risk of heart disease and stroke

nutrients.name: Vitamin C
nutrients.risks: Excessive amounts (over 2000 mg per day) can potentially cause kidney stones, severe diarrhea, nausea, and stomach cramps

sources.label: 7 Impressive Ways Vitamin C Benefits Your Body

nutrients.benefits: Boosts immunity, aids in collagen production for wound healing, enhances iron absorption, lowers blood pressure, and may reduce the risk of certain cancers, heart disease, and cataracts

nutrients.name: Added sugars
nutrients.risks: Excessive consumption is associated with increased risks of obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cognitive decline, and some cancers

sources.label: Relationship between Added Sugars Consumption and Chronic Disease Risk Factors: Current Understanding

nutrients.benefits: No scientifically proven benefits of consuming added sugars

nutrients.name: Magnesium
nutrients.risks: Excessive magnesium intake, particularly from supplements, can lead to side effects like diarrhea, nausea, low blood pressure, and in severe cases, irregular heartbeat, respiratory distress, and even coma
nutrients.benefits: Plays a vital role in bone health, cardiovascular health, migraine prevention, and regulating blood sugar levels, potentially reducing the risk of conditions like diabetes, osteoporosis, and heart disease

nutrients.name: Zinc
nutrients.risks: Excessive zinc intake can interfere with copper absorption, potentially leading to anemia and weakened immune function, and may cause nausea, vomiting, and other digestive issues.
nutrients.benefits: Zinc is essential for immune function, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and protein production, supporting overall health and growth.
